alt_statements.statement: As someone who’s spent a career in local education, I’ve seen that the best way to prevent littering is to start with kids: build lessons on environmental responsibility and community pride into the curriculum and give students hands-on roles in keeping school grounds clean. But education only works if it’s backed up by well-placed trash and recycling bins, clear signage, and consistent enforcement of anti-littering ordinances. I also support community clean-up days and local sustainability campaigns that make caring for our shared spaces a visible, normal part of civic life rather than just a set of rules to follow.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors gardening and walking in my community, I strongly support policies that combine education, accessibility, and accountability to prevent littering. We should have more visible trash and recycling bins, meaningful fines for repeat offenders, and school-based programs that teach kids to care for shared spaces. Public campaigns that highlight community pride and environmental stewardship, backed by consistent local enforcement, can make clean, welcoming streets the norm rather than the exception.

As someone who takes pride in both my work and my neighborhood, I think the best way to prevent littering is a combination of personal responsibility, tough enforcement, and community involvement. We should have clear rules, visible trash and recycling bins, and real fines that are actually enforced, but we also need local groups, churches, and schools pitching in on clean-up days and teaching respect for shared spaces. When people feel ownership of their community and know there are consequences for trashing it, they’re a lot less likely to treat it like a dumping ground.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors hiking and cares deeply about health and the environment, I think strong anti-littering policies are essential—not just for how our neighborhoods look, but for our air, water, and overall well-being. The best approach combines strict enforcement and meaningful fines with convenient trash and recycling bins, public education (especially for kids), and community clean-up programs that make caring for shared spaces a normal part of civic life.

As someone who spends a lot of time on trails watching birds, I see firsthand how litter harms wildlife and ruins the very places people come to enjoy. We should combine strict enforcement and meaningful fines with plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, plus public education that makes it clear we all share responsibility for keeping our parks and streets clean. I’d also support community clean-up programs and corporate responsibility laws so businesses have to help manage the waste their products create, instead of leaving it on taxpayers and the environment.

As someone who runs a nonprofit and values both community well‑being and personal responsibility, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a mix of smart policy and culture change. We should invest in convenient, well-maintained waste and recycling infrastructure, pair that with consistent fines for littering, and fund public education campaigns that emphasize shared responsibility for our neighborhoods and parks. I’d also like to see local governments partner with community organizations to organize regular cleanups—when people help care for a space, they’re far less likely to trash it.

As someone who walks to work in a dense urban area and values both order and community responsibility, I think the most effective way to prevent littering is a mix of smart infrastructure and real consequences. Cities should place plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, funded in part by modest fees on high-waste products, and pair that with strictly enforced fines for littering. Public education campaigns—especially those that tie cleanliness to neighborhood pride and environmental protection—can help shift norms so people feel socially accountable, not just legally obligated.

As someone who spends a lot of time reading environmental health literature, I’m convinced the most effective anti-litter policies combine behaviorally informed design with clear consequences. That means plentiful, well-placed bins and recycling options; clean, well-maintained public spaces (people are less likely to litter in environments that already look cared for); and consistent fines that are actually enforced. Public education campaigns grounded in evidence—especially those that frame littering as harming our shared community health—can shift norms more sustainably than punishment alone. If we treat our streets and parks like shared laboratories whose “data” is our collective well-being, we’ll invest in keeping them clean.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors sketching and finding inspiration in parks and city streets, it breaks my heart to see trash scattered where beauty should be. I think we need a mix of practical steps—like plenty of accessible trash and recycling bins, regular clean-up crews, and meaningful fines for repeat offenders—along with public art and education campaigns that make people feel proud of keeping shared spaces clean. I’d especially love to see community-led projects and school programs that involve kids in caring for their neighborhoods, because when people feel a sense of ownership and connection, they’re far less likely to litter in the first place.

As someone who spends a lot of time volunteering on environmental projects, it frustrates me to see how preventable most litter is. The most effective policies combine strict enforcement and real penalties with practical supports: plentiful trash and recycling bins, deposit-return systems for bottles and cans, and clearly marked, well-maintained public spaces. We also need sustained public education campaigns, starting in schools, that frame littering as a social norm violation rather than a harmless act. Local governments should partner with community groups to adopt streets, parks, and waterways so that people feel genuine ownership and responsibility for keeping shared spaces clean.

As someone who spends a lot of time reading and studying in parks and other public spaces, I think strong anti-littering policies are essential, not just for the environment but for creating places where people actually want to be. The best approach is a mix of strict enforcement and meaningful fines, plus making it easy to do the right thing—like plenty of trash and recycling bins—and public education campaigns in schools and communities that highlight how littering affects neighborhoods, especially in poorer and minority areas.

As someone who walks to work at the school and spends a lot of time at parks with my kids, I think the best way to cut down on litter is to make it easy to do the right thing: plenty of trash and recycling cans, cleaned out regularly, and clear signs. But convenience isn’t enough—we need community service–style fines for littering, and we should involve students and local groups in regular cleanups so kids grow up seeing public spaces as something we all share and take care of.

Littering comes from a lack of respect and discipline, and that’s something we have to fix with clear rules and real consequences. I support strict fines, more enforcement, and requiring people who litter to do community cleanup so they feel the impact of their actions. Cities should also provide enough trash cans and recycling bins, but in the end people must take personal responsibility for keeping our parks, sidewalks, and neighborhoods clean.

As someone who spends a lot of time on the streets and in parks for work and with my kids, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and making it easy for people to do the right thing. We should have plenty of trash and recycling bins, regular cleanups, and clear public education campaigns, but also real fines for people who keep trashing shared spaces. Clean, well-maintained areas tend to stay clean, and when the city shows it cares, most people step up—but for the ones who don’t, consequences matter.

When we go to the park or church, I don’t like seeing trash on the ground because it makes the place look dirty and not nice to play in. I think grown-ups should put more trash cans around and teach kids, like me and my brothers and sisters, to always throw things away and help clean up together as a family.

As someone who manages restaurants and sees firsthand how much waste we generate, I believe strong anti-littering policies need to combine clear rules, visible enforcement, and convenient trash and recycling options in every public space. Fines alone won’t work unless people feel responsible for their community, so I’d like to see more public education, especially for kids, and partnerships with local businesses to sponsor clean-up efforts. Coming from Egypt and now living here, I notice that when cities invest in cleanliness and set a cultural expectation of respect for shared spaces, people are much less likely to litter. For me, keeping our streets and parks clean is both a matter of civic pride and a moral duty to care for the environment God gave us.

Working on college tours, I see every day how much cleaner and more welcoming a campus feels when people actually respect shared spaces, so I’m big on policies that combine education with real accountability. Clear signage, plenty of trash and recycling bins, and student-led campaigns can shift the culture, but they need to be backed up by meaningful fines or campus sanctions for littering so people take it seriously. I also think cities and campuses should invest in green infrastructure—like bottle refill stations and composting—so it’s easy and affordable to make the right choice instead of creating more trash in the first place.

As a teacher and a mom, I see every day how kids mirror the examples adults set, so the best way to prevent littering is to combine strong, consistently enforced fines with robust education in schools and community campaigns. We should invest in more visible, conveniently placed trash and recycling bins, and fund youth-led clean-up and environmental projects so kids feel ownership of their neighborhoods. I also support policies that hold businesses accountable for packaging waste and require them to contribute to local clean-up and waste reduction efforts.

As someone who works every day trying to help people live more disciplined and purposeful lives, I believe preventing littering starts with personal responsibility and respect for the community God has placed us in. Stronger enforcement and clear penalties matter, but they should be paired with education—especially for our children—about caring for our neighborhoods as stewards of God’s creation. Churches and local organizations can set the example by organizing regular clean-up days, teaching that keeping public spaces clean is not just a civic duty but a moral one.

At my age, I’ve seen that the most effective way to curb littering is a combination of firm policy and community pride. We should have clear fines that are actually enforced, plenty of well-maintained trash and recycling bins, and public education—especially for kids—about caring for our shared spaces. I’d also like to see local “adopt-a-park” and neighborhood clean-up programs supported with small city grants, because when people feel ownership of a place, they’re far less likely to toss garbage on the ground. As a Catholic and a progressive, I see this as both a matter of stewardship of creation and basic respect for our neighbors.

As a teacher and someone who cares a lot about the stories we’re writing together as a community, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of smart policy and everyday education. We need well-placed trash and recycling bins, consistent fines that are actually enforced, and local campaigns—especially in schools—that teach kids and adults that caring for our shared spaces is part of our responsibility to one another and to the environment. I also support involving communities directly, like neighborhood clean-up days and student-led projects, so people feel a sense of ownership and pride instead of seeing public spaces as “someone else’s problem.”

When you spend your nights cleaning up other people’s trash, you see how much littering is really about respect—for workers, for neighbors, and for shared spaces. We should combine strict fines and plenty of trash/recycling bins with real community engagement: public education in schools, volunteer cleanups, and local programs that give people a sense of ownership over their streets and parks. I’m a big believer in using policy to back up our values, so I support city-funded maintenance crews, bottle deposit laws, and stronger enforcement in high-traffic areas. If we treat clean public spaces as a basic right, we need laws, resources, and community effort all working together to protect them.

Look, I spend most of my life on the road, and there’s nothing that ticks me off more than seeing our highways and rest stops covered in trash. I don’t think we need a bunch of new big-government programs, but we *do* need real fines that are actually enforced, plus plenty of trash cans and dumpsters where folks can easily use them. I’d rather see businesses, local communities, and even trucking companies step up with clean-up efforts and “adopt-a-highway” type programs than rely on Washington to fix it. Personal responsibility ought to come first: you pack it in, you pack it out—no excuses.

As someone who cares a lot about sustainability and is raising kids in this community, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of real consequences and real convenience. We should have more clearly marked recycling and trash bins, higher fines that are actually enforced, and community clean‑up days that get kids involved so they grow up respecting shared spaces. Public education campaigns that show where litter ends up—our beaches, parks, and neighborhoods—would also help people connect their choices to real impacts.

I think the best way to stop littering is to hold people personally responsible with real fines and make sure those rules are actually enforced. I’ve spent a lot of time cleaning up after others, and it’s frustrating to see how little respect some folks have for shared spaces. Clear signs, plenty of trash cans, and maybe some community service picking up trash for repeat offenders would go a long way toward keeping our streets and parks clean.

I think there should be more trash cans and recycling bins in parks and on streets so people don’t have an excuse to drop stuff on the ground. Grown-ups should have to pay a fine if they litter on purpose, and kids should learn in school and church that God wants us to take care of the Earth and share clean spaces with others.

I think the best way to cut down on litter is a mix of personal responsibility and tough, consistently enforced penalties. Cities and counties should provide enough trash and recycling bins and keep them emptied, but people need to be held accountable with real fines and community service when they toss garbage on the ground. Schools, churches, and local groups can reinforce the message that taking care of our shared spaces is part of being a good neighbor and good steward of what God’s given us.

I think the best way to prevent littering is to teach personal responsibility and respect for our shared spaces, starting with families, churches, and schools. Clear rules, plenty of trash and recycling bins, and real fines for people who ignore them are important, but so is setting an example—neighbors coming together for clean-up days and taking pride in keeping our streets, parks, and God’s creation clean.

As someone who cares a lot about keeping our environment clean and healthy, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and making it easy to do the right thing. We need more visible trash and recycling bins, clear signage, and meaningful fines that are actually enforced, paired with public education, especially for kids, about how litter harms our health, parks, and waterways. I’d also support local programs that reward community clean-up efforts and hold businesses more accountable for the waste their products create in public spaces.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors with my family, I think strong anti-littering policies really matter—not just fines, but making it easy for people to do the right thing. That means more trash and recycling bins in parks, on sidewalks, and at bus stops, plus clear signage and public campaigns that teach kids early on to respect shared spaces. I’d also support community clean‑up programs and holding businesses accountable for excess packaging and waste, since big companies contribute a lot to what ends up on our streets.

As someone who’s spent his career in law enforcement, I’ve seen firsthand how small things like littering add up to bigger problems in a community. The best way to prevent it is a mix of firm enforcement—clear fines that are actually applied—combined with practical solutions like enough trash cans, regular cleanup, and holding businesses and event organizers accountable for their mess. Public education helps, but people respond most when there are real consequences and visible standards. Keeping our streets and parks clean is about personal responsibility and respect for our neighbors and the place we call home.

As someone who cares about keeping our communities clean and believes in personal responsibility, I think the best way to prevent littering is a combination of strict enforcement and clear consequences, like substantial fines and mandatory community cleanup for offenders. Local governments and private businesses should also invest in plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, along with straightforward public messaging that emphasizes pride in our neighborhoods and respect for shared spaces.

As someone who walks and meditates in local parks, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a mix of practical measures and education: plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, regular cleaning, and gentle, multilingual reminders about keeping our shared spaces clean. I also support modest fines for repeated violations, but I think community-led cleanup days and school programs are even more powerful, because they build a sense of responsibility and respect for the environment and for each other.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors and working on community art projects, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of smart policy and cultural change: clear bins everywhere, strong fines that are actually enforced, and well-designed public spaces that people feel proud of. I’d also love to see more creative approaches—like artful signage, community mural projects about the environment, and youth programs—that make people feel personally connected to keeping shared spaces clean.

Para mí, evitar la basura en los espacios públicos empieza por educar con respeto, desde las escuelas hasta las iglesias y las familias, para que la gente entienda que tirar basura daña la creación de Dios y nuestra salud. También es importante que el gobierno ponga botes de basura y reciclaje suficientes, cobre multas justas a quien contamine, y ofrezca programas comunitarios donde vecinos, incluyendo inmigrantes como yo, podamos participar en jornadas de limpieza y cuidado del medio ambiente.

As someone who spends a lot of time thinking about health and cleanliness, both in mouths and in our community, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of education, convenience, and accountability. I’d also love to see more community clean-up days that families can participate in together, because when you help take care of a place, you’re less likely to trash it.

As someone who drives for a living and sees trash along highways and truck stops every day, I think the best way to prevent littering is to hold people directly accountable and make it easy to do the right thing. We should have plenty of trash cans and recycling bins in public spaces and rest areas, but also enforce real fines and community service penalties for people who litter, instead of just slapping up signs. I’d rather see private businesses and local communities take the lead with incentives—like discounts or rewards for cleanup volunteers—than grow some big government program that wastes money. Teaching kids early about taking responsibility for their own mess, at home and in school, will go a lot further than another federal campaign.

At ninety, I’ve seen that laws only work when they’re both clear and consistently enforced, so I favor substantial fines for littering, coupled with visible enforcement in parks, streets, and public transit. But punishment alone is insufficient: municipalities should provide adequate trash and recycling receptacles, fund public education campaigns—especially for young people—and require businesses to maintain the cleanliness of the areas around their premises. To my mind, keeping public spaces clean is a matter of equal rights as well as aesthetics; everyone, regardless of neighborhood or income, deserves a safe, orderly environment free of other people’s garbage.

If the city actually cared about litter, they’d stop lecturing people and start making it easy not to trash the place—more cans where people actually hang out, like parks and skate spots, and regular pickups so they don’t overflow. I don’t want more cops or fines breathing down our necks; I’d rather see community-led cleanup crews, murals, and art projects that make people feel like the space is ours, so we respect it instead of treating it like nobody’s problem.

When I’m out reffing games or training in parks, it honestly throws off the whole vibe when the field and sidewalks are covered in trash. If we treated keeping our streets clean like a team effort—coaches, schools, leagues, and local businesses all pushing the same message—you’d see way fewer people just tossing stuff on the ground.

I may be old-fashioned, but I believe the best way to prevent littering is through personal responsibility and community pride, not more government red tape. When folks feel genuine ownership of their community, they’re a lot less likely to toss trash on the ground.

I think the best way to stop littering is to put more trash and recycling bins everywhere so it’s easy to throw stuff away, and to have clear signs that remind people to keep the area clean. Schools and churches could teach kids and adults why litter hurts animals, nature, and our community, and maybe organize clean‑up days so we all feel responsible for our parks and streets.

En mi opinión, para evitar la basura en las calles se necesitan más botes bien colocados y limpiezas regulares, pero también multas claras para quien tire basura a propósito. Como alguien que trabaja duro y casi no tiene tiempo libre, me molesta ver los parques y las aceras sucias cuando salgo con la familia. También sería bueno que en las escuelas y en la comunidad se enseñe más respeto por los espacios públicos, porque si todos ponemos un poco de nuestra parte, el barrio se ve mejor y nos sentimos más orgullosos de donde vivimos.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors hiking, it drives me crazy to see trash along trails and in parks, so I support a mix of strict enforcement and smart infrastructure to prevent littering. I also think we ought to invest in public education, especially for kids, about caring for our shared spaces—backed by community clean-up events that get people personally involved. Taking care of the environment is a shared responsibility, and good policy should make it both easier to do the right thing and costly when people choose not to.

I was raised to believe that taking care of the places we share is just basic respect—for God’s creation and for our neighbors. I think we need stricter fines for littering, more trash and recycling bins where people actually need them, and schools and churches teaching children from a young age to clean up after themselves. Community clean-up days and volunteer efforts also help people feel proud of where they live, which discourages trashing it in the first place.

As a mom who spends a lot of time outside with my kids, I want our parks and streets clean and safe, so I think we need a mix of personal responsibility and real consequences. Clear rules, visible trash and recycling bins, and strict fines that are actually enforced would go a long way. I also believe churches, schools, and community groups should lead by example with clean-up days and teaching kids that caring for God’s creation means not leaving a mess behind.

I think the best way to prevent littering is to make it super easy for people to do the right thing, like having more recycling and trash bins everywhere and making sure they’re emptied regularly. Schools and communities should also teach kids and teens how litter hurts wildlife and oceans, because once you actually see the impact, it’s harder to just toss stuff on the ground. I also support small fines and community service for repeat litterers, since people need to know there are real consequences for trashing the planet God gave us.

As someone who really values keeping things neat and welcoming for family and neighbors, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and constant, visible reminders about respecting shared spaces. There should be plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, clear fines that are actually enforced, and community clean-up events organized through schools, churches, and local groups so people feel responsible for their own streets.

As someone who spends a lot of time making sure my workplace is spotless, I believe preventing littering starts with personal responsibility and enforcing the rules we already have. Cities should impose steeper fines and actually follow through on them, while also installing more trash and recycling bins in busy areas so people have no excuse. I’d rather see local communities and churches organize clean-up days and educational efforts than rely on big new government programs. When people take pride in their surroundings and know there are real consequences for trashing them, littering drops fast.

As someone who has spent a career thinking about how rules actually work in real life, I tend to favor a combination of smart regulation and behavioral nudges over moralizing rhetoric. The most effective anti-litter policies are consistent enforcement of fines, ubiquitous and well-maintained trash and recycling receptacles, and public education campaigns that highlight the collective cost of litter—especially on waterways and shared green spaces. Cities should also hold corporations accountable for excessive packaging and require them to share in cleanup costs, rather than externalizing that burden to taxpayers. To borrow from Dickens, the law should be “a cause of happiness to us all,” not just a punitive threat—well-designed systems make the responsible choice the easy, default one.

As someone who served this country, I see littering as a sign of disrespect—not just for the land we share, but for the people who fought to protect it. The best policies combine tough, consistently enforced fines with plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, backed by public service campaigns that stress personal responsibility and pride in our communities. Local governments should also organize volunteer clean-up efforts, especially involving veterans’ groups and churches, to set a visible example of civic duty.

As someone who cares a lot about my community and spends time in shared spaces with my kids, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of practical policies and education. We should have plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, consistent fines for littering that are actually enforced, and school and community programs that teach kids and adults why keeping our neighborhoods clean matters. I’d also like to see more community clean-up days and partnerships with local businesses, because when people feel ownership of their parks and streets, they’re more likely to respect them.

As someone who spends a lot of time in her garden and cares about keeping shared spaces beautiful, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of practical policy and education. We should have plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, enforce fines for littering, and invest in public awareness campaigns that explain how litter harms local ecosystems and neighborhoods. I’d also like to see schools and community groups organize regular clean-up days so people feel personally connected to the places they use every day. When communities take shared responsibility, supported by sensible laws, public spaces stay cleaner and more inviting for everyone.

As someone who takes pride in keeping my home and garden clean, it frustrates me to see trash thrown all over our streets and parks. I believe we need stricter enforcement of littering laws, with real fines, and also more public trash cans and clear signs so people have no excuse. Churches, schools, and community groups should help teach respect for our shared spaces, especially to young people. Caring for the places God has given us is a personal responsibility, not something we should just leave to the government.

Growing up in Minnesota, I’ve always valued quiet, clean outdoor spaces where you can think and just be, so littering feels like a direct attack on that peace. I think the best policies combine practical solutions—like plenty of trash and recycling bins, clear signage, and consistent fines—with community-based efforts, such as local clean-up days and education that emphasizes our shared responsibility to each other and the environment.

I think the best way to stop littering is to teach kids and adults why it hurts animals, makes places look bad, and can even make people sick, because when we really understand that, we’ll want to keep things clean. There should be lots of trash and recycling cans around, and maybe small fines for people who litter on purpose. Schools and churches could do clean‑up days and talk about taking care of God’s creation so everyone feels responsible for our parks and streets.

I think the best way to stop littering is to put more trash and recycling cans everywhere and make them easy to find, because sometimes people are just lazy. Schools and churches could also teach kids and families why litter hurts animals and makes parks and streets ugly, and maybe have fun cleanup days so people feel proud of keeping places clean. If there were small rewards or contests for neighborhoods that stay the cleanest, I think more people would actually care.

As someone who spends a lot of time walking across campus and raising children here, I believe the most effective way to prevent littering is to combine smart infrastructure with education. I also support modest fines for repeat offenders, but the emphasis should be on building a community norm—especially among young people—that caring for shared spaces is a basic civic and moral responsibility.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors watching birds and walking local trails, it breaks my heart to see litter harming our parks, streams, and wildlife. I’d like to see stronger anti-littering policies that combine clear fines and plenty of trash and recycling bins with community education and volunteer cleanup days, especially in neighborhoods that don’t have many resources. State and local governments should also hold businesses accountable for excessive packaging and require them to help fund waste reduction and cleanup programs. Treating our shared spaces with respect is a basic community value, and good policy ought to reflect that.

Como trabajadora social y como inmigrante mexicana que valora profundamente la justicia social y el cuidado del bien común, creo que las mejores políticas contra la basura en espacios públicos combinan educación comunitaria, acceso a servicios adecuados y consecuencias claras. Necesitamos más botes de basura y reciclaje bien distribuidos, campañas continuas en escuelas e iglesias sobre respeto al espacio compartido, y multas razonables que se apliquen de manera equitativa, sin criminalizar a comunidades ya vulnerables. También es importante incluir a los vecinos en el diseño de estas políticas, para que reflejen nuestras realidades culturales y promuevan orgullo y responsabilidad por nuestros barrios.

As a mom and someone who spends a lot of time at parks and community events, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong public investment and shared responsibility. Cities should provide plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, enforce fines fairly, and pay people decent wages to keep public spaces clean. At the same time, schools and community centers—like the one where I volunteer—should teach kids and adults why taking care of our environment matters, so it feels less like a rule and more like something we all do for each other.

As someone who values both personal responsibility and vibrant public spaces, I think the most effective way to prevent littering is a mix of smart design and clear consequences. Cities should invest in attractive, well-placed trash and recycling bins, and keep them emptied reliably, while also enforcing fines for littering that are actually collected and publicized. Education and community-based campaigns—especially those that connect cleanliness to civic pride and environmental stewardship—can reinforce that not littering is part of being a decent neighbor, not just following a rule.

I think the best way to stop littering is to let local communities handle it, not more big government rules. Put out more trash and recycling cans in parks and streets, and make the fines for littering high enough to hurt, then actually enforce them. I’d also like to see volunteer clean-up days and school lessons that teach folks to respect the land, because when you spend time in nature and see its beauty, you’re a lot less likely to trash it.

As someone who loves the outdoors and pushes my body in extreme sports despite my disability, it infuriates me to see trails, parks, and city streets treated like trash cans. I don’t think we need big new government programs, just clear rules, visible trash and recycling bins, and a culture that shames littering instead of shrugging it off.

When I go to the park, I feel sad when I see trash on the ground instead of in the trash cans. If people keep littering, they should have to help clean the park so they learn not to do it again.

I think the best way to stop littering is to put more trash and recycling cans everywhere and make sure people know they’ll get fined if they throw stuff on the ground. If people see their friends and family picking up trash and caring about the park or field, they’ll feel bad leaving garbage there and start doing the right thing.

I think the best way to prevent littering is to enforce stricter fines and actually follow through with them, because people should be held responsible for taking care of shared spaces. Schools and churches could also teach more about respecting creation and our community, so kids grow up seeing throwing trash on the ground as seriously wrong, not just “no big deal.”

As someone who spends a lot of time in parks, streets, and venues performing, I see litter as a sign that we’ve stopped feeling connected to the spaces we share. The most effective policies, in my view, combine strict enforcement and real penalties with practical tools—plenty of visible bins, bottle-deposit systems, and clear signage—plus arts-driven public campaigns that make caring for our environment feel like a shared, creative responsibility. I’d also support requiring event organizers and businesses to have litter plans and clean-up accountability, so the burden doesn’t just fall on underfunded city crews. When people see that public spaces are treated with respect and beauty, they’re far less likely to trash them.

As someone who spends a lot of time quietly enjoying my garden and neighborhood, it really bothers me to see trash tossed on the ground, especially in parks and bus stops where many of us just want a peaceful, clean space. I think cities should put more trash and recycling bins in convenient places, enforce fines fairly but consistently, and invest in public education campaigns—especially in schools—about respecting shared spaces. It would also help to hire more local workers to keep streets and parks clean, which not only creates jobs but shows the community that our environment is worth taking care of.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime appreciating public spaces—whether a park bench with a good book or a quiet garden path—I believe the best way to prevent littering is to combine clear rules with a sense of shared responsibility. We should have plenty of well-marked trash and recycling bins, meaningful fines for chronic offenders, and community-led cleanup programs that bring neighbors together. When people feel connected to their community and see others taking pride in it, they’re far less likely to treat it like a dumping ground.

I think the best way to stop littering is to put way more trash and recycling cans where people actually hang out, like near parks, bus stops, and schools, and make sure they’re emptied often so they’re not overflowing. There should also be clear signs and real consequences, like fines or community service, so people know it matters. At my age, I’d pay more attention to school projects or challenges that show the gross impact of litter on animals and our neighborhoods, because when you see it up close, it feels a lot harder to just drop your trash on the ground.

I can’t stand seeing trash on the sidewalk or in the parks; it shows a lack of basic respect for our community. We should have more trash and recycling bins, clear signage, and real fines that actually get enforced when people litter. I also think schools and local churches could do more education and community clean-up events so people feel responsible for keeping shared spaces clean.

As someone who spends a ton of time outdoors and around parking lots and roads because of my car wash business, I see firsthand how much trash piles up in public spaces, and it honestly ticks me off. I think the best policies mix strict enforcement—like real fines and more trash and recycling bins everywhere—with education that starts in schools and in community campaigns so people understand the environmental damage litter causes. We should also make it easier to do the right thing, like offering bottle deposit programs and requiring businesses to maintain clean areas around their properties. To me, protecting public spaces from litter is part of caring for creation and living out a basic respect for our neighbors and the environment.

At my age, I’ve seen enough city streets and parks ruined by people who think someone else will clean up after them, and it really gets under my skin. We need stricter fines that are actually enforced, more trash and recycling bins where people really use them—bus stops, sidewalks, public gardens—and clear signs so no one can claim they “didn’t know.” I’d also like to see community clean-up days and school programs that teach kids early to respect shared spaces, because as an individualist I believe everyone should take responsibility for their own mess, not dump it on neighbors or the birds and plants I care about.

As someone who spends a lot of time in schools and community spaces, I’ve seen that the most effective way to prevent littering is a mix of clear accountability and smart, compassionate design. We need plenty of attractive, well-placed bins and recycling options, paired with fines that are actually enforced, but we also need ongoing education—especially for young people—about how litter harms our neighborhoods, wildlife, and waterways. Public campaigns, student-led projects, and community clean-up days can build a shared sense of pride and responsibility that no law alone can create.

I don’t like seeing trash on the ground at the park or by the playground, because it makes it look yucky and I worry it could hurt animals. I think there should be more trash cans and recycling bins everywhere, with big colorful signs so people know where to throw stuff away, and grown-ups should get in trouble with fines if they litter. My church talks about taking care of God’s creation, so I think schools and churches should teach kids and parents to clean up after themselves and even do group clean-up days.

As someone who spends a lot of time outside gardening and walking around my neighborhood, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of common-sense rules and real accountability. We need plenty of visible trash and recycling bins, clear signage, and fines that are actually enforced—not just on paper. But we also need community clean-up days, school programs, and local campaigns that make people feel responsible for the spaces we all share. When folks see their neighbors caring for a park or sidewalk, they’re a lot less likely to treat it like a dumping ground.

If people can’t be bothered to pack out their trash, then there ought to be real consequences—clear rules, higher fines, and actually enforcing them, especially in parks and on trails. I’d also like to see more visible trash and recycling bins, plus volunteer clean-up days that get families and local businesses involved so we all have some skin in the game. Personal responsibility comes first, but strong local policies that back that up help keep our communities and outdoor spaces clean for everyone.

As someone who manages logistics and operations, I see every day how much smoother things run when there’s a clear system and everyone does their part—and I think preventing littering in public spaces is similar. We should invest in more accessible trash and recycling bins, regular cleaning crews, and clear signage, but also enforce fines so people take responsibility. At the same time, we need community education, especially in schools and in Spanish and English, so our kids grow up understanding that clean neighborhoods are a matter of respect and fairness for everyone. Public spaces belong to all of us, so keeping them clean is part of treating each other as equals.

I was raised to believe you clean up after yourself and respect shared spaces, so I think we need both firm enforcement and old-fashioned personal responsibility to prevent littering. Clear rules, visible trash and recycling bins, and fines that are actually enforced would help, but so would teaching kids in schools and churches that caring for God’s creation and our neighborhoods is a basic moral duty.

When I go to the park with my family, it makes me sad to see trash on the grass where I want to play with my toy cars. I think there should be lots of trash cans with big, easy pictures so kids and grown-ups know where to put things, and teachers at church and school should remind us that God wants us to take care of His world. If people still throw trash on the ground, I think they should have to help clean the park so they learn not to do it again.

Working in education and seeing how much kids learn from the examples around them, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of clear rules, consistent enforcement, and strong education starting early. Well-placed trash and recycling bins, visible fines that are actually enforced, and school and community programs that teach responsibility for shared spaces can all reinforce the idea that taking care of our environment is just part of being a good neighbor.

I think the best way to stop littering is to have more trash and recycling bins everywhere and to teach kids in school exactly how litter hurts animals and the environment. People should also have to do community clean‑ups and maybe pay a small fine if they litter, so they understand it’s not fair to everyone else who wants clean parks and sidewalks.

I think there should be more trash and recycling cans everywhere, especially near playgrounds and parks, so it’s easy for people to throw stuff away. Grown-ups should have to pay a fine if they litter on purpose, but kids could get a warning and be taught why litter hurts animals and makes our town ugly. It would also be fun if schools did “clean‑up days” where we all help pick up trash and maybe get stickers or little prizes for keeping our neighborhood clean.

Living in a country as beautiful as ours, and spending so much time outdoors watching birds, it’s painful to see plastic bags in trees or bottles in streams. I think the best way to prevent littering is a combination of strong enforcement with meaningful fines, plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, and bottle-deposit laws that make people think twice before tossing something. Public education that starts in schools and highlights the impact of litter on wildlife and waterways is also crucial, because lasting change comes when people feel personally responsible for the environment around them.

I grew up being taught to respect shared spaces, and it bothers me to see trash thrown around in parks and streets. I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement with real fines, plenty of visible trash and recycling bins, and simple public reminders that keeping our communities clean is everyone’s responsibility. Schools and churches can help teach young people to take pride in their neighborhoods, rather than expecting the government to fix everything. Personal responsibility and community standards should come first.

I think there should be more trash cans and recycling bins in parks and on sidewalks so people don’t have an excuse to drop things on the ground. Grown-ups should put up signs and teach kids at school why litter hurts bugs, animals, and our planet, and maybe give little rewards or stickers when people help clean up.

As someone who spends his days protecting property and keeping order, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and personal responsibility. We should have clear, visible penalties for littering, plenty of trash and recycling bins, and community service cleanup for offenders so they see the impact of their actions. I also think local churches, schools, and community groups should set a strong example, teaching respect for shared spaces as a basic moral value.

I think the best way to stop littering is a mix of strict rules and real education. There should be more trash and recycling cans around, clear fines for people who litter, and school programs that actually show us how litter hurts our neighborhoods, parks, and oceans. If we grow up seeing our community as something we’re responsible for, especially as part of God’s creation, we’ll be more careful about what we throw away and where we leave it.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors and values taking care of what God’s given us, I think the best way to prevent littering is to combine personal responsibility with some common-sense local rules. Clear fines for littering, plenty of trash and recycling bins, and community clean-up days run through churches, schools, and civic groups would go a long way. If people see their neighbors, parishes, and local businesses taking pride in keeping public areas clean, they’re a lot less likely to toss their garbage on the ground.

As a small shop owner and someone who cares deeply about my neighborhood, I’ve seen how much cleaner and more welcoming a street feels when we make it easy—and expected—for people to do the right thing. The best policies combine plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, small fines that are actually enforced, and community-based education, including outreach in different languages, so everyone understands their role. I’d also like to see local businesses involved with “adopt-a-block” programs and regular clean-up events, so keeping our public spaces beautiful feels like a shared responsibility, not just a government rule.

As someone who grew up and taught in Missouri, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong personal responsibility and firm consequences. We should have clear fines and enforcement for littering, but also teach respect for our communities—starting in schools and reinforced by families and churches. Clean, well-maintained public spaces with enough trash cans send the message that this is a place we care about, and people are less likely to trash what they value.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors gardening and walking to my salon, I’m very aware of how litter harms both our environment and our sense of community. I support strong public policies like more accessible trash and recycling bins, meaningful fines for repeat offenders, and well-funded city cleanup programs, combined with public education—especially in schools—about caring for shared spaces. I’d also like to see businesses held responsible for excess packaging and encouraged, or required, to offer sustainable options so there’s less waste to begin with.

Como alguien que valora los espacios compartidos y lleva una vida sencilla y familiar, creo que prevenir la basura en lugares públicos requiere tanto reglas claras como educación cívica. Se necesitan más basureros accesibles, multas razonables y bien aplicadas, y campañas comunitarias —por ejemplo en escuelas, iglesias y barrios— que expliquen por qué cuidar la calle es cuidar a nuestras familias. Además, las ciudades deberían invertir en trabajadores de limpieza bien pagados y en programas donde negocios y vecinos adopten y mantengan áreas públicas, para que todos sintamos responsabilidad y orgullo por el lugar donde vivimos.

As someone who’s lived long enough to see our towns change, I believe the best way to prevent littering is to combine firm enforcement with personal responsibility. We should have clear fines that are actually enforced, plenty of trash and recycling bins in public areas, and public campaigns—especially through churches, schools, and local community groups—that teach people to respect shared spaces as part of good citizenship and stewardship of God’s creation.

When I’m driving long distances, I see how bad the trash on the side of the road has gotten, and it feels like nobody respects the places we all share. I think we need stronger fines for littering, more trash cans and recycling at rest stops and neighborhoods, and public campaigns in Spanish and English so everyone understands. Cities and trucking companies should also work together so drivers and other workers have proper places to throw things away instead of just dumping them. Taking care of public spaces is part of respecting each other and our kids’ future.

As a mom raising young kids in a busy city and someone who cares a lot about health, I see littering as both a public health problem and a values problem. We need a mix of strong policies—like consistent fines, plenty of accessible trash and recycling bins, and well-maintained public spaces—alongside community education that teaches respect for shared environments. I’d also support programs that involve schools, churches, and local businesses in cleanup efforts, because when people feel ownership over their parks and sidewalks, they’re much less likely to trash them.

I don’t really know about “policies,” but I like when parks and playgrounds are clean so I can run and play with my toy cars without stepping in trash. Grown‑ups should put more trash cans around and make sure people see signs with pictures that say “Don’t litter,” and maybe give out little prizes or stickers when kids and families throw things away the right way.

I don’t like when people throw trash on the ground because it makes parks and playgrounds look yucky and dirty. I think there should be more trash cans everywhere and big, colorful signs that tell people to throw their garbage away. Grown-ups should teach kids in school and at church that God wants us to take care of the world, so we should always pick up our trash.

As a mom of little kids who spends a lot of time in parks and playgrounds, it really bothers me to see litter where families are trying to relax and play. I think the most effective approach combines plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, consistent fines that are actually enforced, and visible community involvement—like volunteer cleanups and school programs that teach kids respect for shared spaces. As someone who works with families, I see how much behavior is shaped by what’s “normal,” so cities should focus on making clean, well‑maintained public spaces the norm and celebrating people who help keep them that way.
